channel.title: Time to prawn some nubs
channel.description:
Is the following a legit statement in Java [br] [code=java]import static java.lang.System.*;[/code]
Using google doesnt count :P
When I get enough people, I'll reveal the answer and what it does

item.title: Time to prawn some nubs
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

frank_:

l2package

giant packages ftw

Read full topic

item.title: Time to prawn some nubs
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

[quote=“byte, post:7, topic:66053”]Yet when I compiled:

import static java.lang.System;
public class test {
	public static void main(String args[]) {
		out.println("Hi");
	}
}

I got the following:

test.java:1: cannot find symbol
symbol  : class lang
location: package java
import static java.lang.System;
                  ^
test.java:1: static import only from classes and interfaces
import static java.lang.System;
^
test.java:5: cannot find symbol
symbol  : variable out
location: class test
                out.println("Hi");
                ^
3 errors

I’m not sure you understand the concept that a static import brings to the table.[/quote]
Oh wait, you’re right.

Scuse me

lel at new sig

Read full topic

item.title: Time to prawn some nubs
item.dc:creator: @byte byte
item.description:
@byte wrote:

Yet when I compiled:

import static java.lang.System;
public class test {
	public static void main(String args[]) {
		out.println("Hi");
	}
}

I got the following:

test.java:1: cannot find symbol
symbol  : class lang
location: package java
import static java.lang.System;
                  ^
test.java:1: static import only from classes and interfaces
import static java.lang.System;
^
test.java:5: cannot find symbol
symbol  : variable out
location: class test
                out.println("Hi");
                ^
3 errors

I’m not sure you understand the concept that a static import brings to the table.

Read full topic

item.title: Time to prawn some nubs
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

Boy, oh boy, I just love making topics where all teh smart Java people come to argue :]

[quote=“byte, post:2, topic:66053”]A static import is allowed although you slaughtered the syntax, meaning your statement is not legit, it should be:

import static java.lang.System.*;

Might I add, personally I believe it was bad language addition, it potentially introduces ambiguities and clouds readability.[/quote]It compiled fine with me.

[quote=“BobDole81, post:3, topic:66053”]I’m thinking of a way you could make this a trick question…but I can’t tell. It shouldn’t (and doesn’t according to my test just now) compile…with the standard library, of course. You could have created a class named lang in a package java with a static field/method named System…in that case it would have technically been valid, but that’s not fair

Or, as byte mentioned, you could have mistyped, and were intending to import java.lang.System.* - that would, of course, be valid.

Might I add, personally I believe it was bad language addition, it potentially introduces ambiguities and clouds readability.

True, but ambiguities already can occur using normal imports. Of course, static imports will never become very essential to any development, but it does come in handy sometimes…if used properly (and sparingly as Sun recommends), it has helped code readability for me imo.[/quote]
Didn’t mistype anything, and no, it’s not a trick question :]

Read full topic

item.title: Time to prawn some nubs
item.dc:creator: @byte byte
item.description:
@byte wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:3, topic:66053”][quote author=byte link=topic=96196.msg991077#msg991077 date=1173508631]
Might I add, personally I believe it was bad language addition, it potentially introduces ambiguities and clouds readability.
[/quote]
True, but ambiguities already can occur using normal imports. Of course, static imports will never become very essential to any development, but it does come in handy sometimes…if used properly (and sparingly as Sun recommends), it has helped code readability for me imo.[/quote]

Yes you are indeed right on the import part, simply my personal opinion on the feature

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I’m thinking of a way you could make this a trick question…but I can’t tell. It shouldn’t (and doesn’t according to my test just now) compile…with the standard library, of course. You could have created a class named lang in a package java with a static field/method named System…in that case it would have technically been valid, but that’s not fair

Or, as byte mentioned, you could have mistyped, and were intending to import java.lang.System.* - that would, of course, be valid.

byte:

Might I add, personally I believe it was bad language addition, it potentially introduces ambiguities and clouds readability.

True, but ambiguities already can occur using normal imports. Of course, static imports will never become very essential to any development, but it does come in handy sometimes…if used properly (and sparingly as Sun recommends), it has helped code readability for me imo.
